column40: One of the most crucial learnings from pitching is the importance of clear and concise communication. Presenters need to articulate their ideas in a manner that is easily understandable to the audience. Being able to convey complex concepts in a straightforward and concise way enhances the effectiveness of the pitch.

column25: The required analysis from different perspectives such as the end consumer and the innovator and understanding what an end consumer wants in a new product was an interesting change of perspective which I will keep in mind in the future. Plus, pitching was a challenging and distinct task which I was not familiar with before starting the module. As such the module introduced me to the basics of pitching and how to successfully pitch a product.
column40:
Research: that researching a problem is the key to solving it. I found this to be true in the case of food waste as the more research the more obvious the conclusion became for me.
Pitching: Through completing this module I was given a chance to attempt a pitch for a solution to an idea. In writing, filming, and preparing the pitch I learned about the basics of video recording, writing for an audience and how to express a complex idea succinctly.
column43: I planned to further develop the skill of innovation through participating in the Nano project and contributing to a report which would have involved the innovative generation of ideas. Due to timetabling difficulties, the Nano project has already passed at the time of writing (where I certainly did improve my innovation skills), so I also intend to participate in further opportunities to further my innovation skills, such as doing internships and work experience with firms and voluntary work with charities, where innovation as a skill is needed.

column25:
Problem Identification: It emphasizes understanding the problem in depth before moving to the solution stage. This is crucial in innovation as a well-defined problem often points towards its solution.

Idea Generation: The module encourages learners to generate a wide range of ideas to address the problem and then select the best one. This divergent and convergent thinking is a key process in innovation.

Validation and Pitching: The module also provides guidance on validating the selected idea, developing a compelling pitch, and identifying key learning outcomes. These steps help in refining the idea and communicating it effectively, which are crucial for bringing an innovative idea to fruition.
column40: Learning the different types of innovation, how to pitch effectively and succinctly, and how to appropriately present in an informative and persuasive way.
column43:
Regularly Practice Idea Generation: Continually seek out opportunities to generate innovative solutions, both in your personal life and your professional work. The more you practice, the better you'll become at coming up with creative ideas and problem-solving strategies.

Seek Diverse Perspectives: Innovation often arises from diverse viewpoints. Try to surround yourself with people who think differently from you and learn from their perspectives.

Stay Informed: The more you know about a variety of topics, the more connections you can make, leading to innovative ideas. Keep learning and staying informed about a wide range of subjects.

Embrace Failure: Not every idea will be a winner, and that's okay. Each failure is an opportunity to learn and refine your approach to innovation. Don't be afraid to take risks and learn from the outcomes.

column25: I found that the problem I had to address, the large amount of food waste in the UK, very interesting and important. Moreover, the structure of this module was excellent, first having to truly understand the problem and sub-problems, then investigating multiple solutions to the problem, and finally pitching your best idea in a clear and persuasive way. This structure was very effective in developing my skill in innovation.
column40:
My most important learnings from this module are: 

1. The importance of truly identifying and understanding the problem that needs the innovative solution 

2. What innovation is and the 4  different types of innovation (architectural, radical, incremental, and disruptive). 

3. How to effectively sell your idea through an elevator pitch using the Steve Sammartino Way.
column43: I will continue to develop the skill of innovation after this module by adopting more creative, nuanced, and unique approaches to problems. Utilising frameworks such as the "Double Diamond" approach, as well as both convergent and divergent thinking will help me achieve this.
